posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
I saw some of the references to the bundling of Epilogue in with wpilibj for 2025. Wanted to try it, so I cloned allwpilib and did a gradlew build and a gradlew publish. I ended up with artifacts in the ~/releases/maven/development with a version of 2023.424242.1.1-20240825105736-1284-gdbeab8b. That looks suspicious to me, since the directory I built from was at commit dbeab8bdd75ab410a2ed75bbc5ab1c07bddea565 (dated Aug 24, 2024).

I can’t figure out how to use the locally built-and-published wpilib. The docs say have this in build.gradle:

I fiddled with mine to get the year to match, and it’s not finding the Epilogue stuff.

What did I do wrong?

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
Epilogue hasn’t been added to GradleRIO yet (and there hasn’t been a new release of GradleRIO rolled for 2025), so it doesn’t know where to find them. You might have some luck adding the dependencies manually (in the dependencies block)- be sure to add the annotation processor too.

Edit:

fovea1959:

I ended up with artifacts in the ~/releases/maven/development with a version of 2023.424242.1.1-20240825105736-1284-gdbeab8b. That looks suspicious to me, since the directory I built from was at commit dbeab8bdd75ab410a2ed75bbc5ab1c07bddea565 (dated Aug 24, 2024).

This is usually caused by out of date tags (which are used to determine the base version). Fetching tags from upstream should fix it:

git fetch --tags --all

posts.name: Will Weiszhaar
posts.cooked: Can you point me to more info on Epilogue? I can’t seem to find anything on google.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
It’s in the “latest” branch of the docs, which I think we may exclude from Google indexing?

At its most basic, telemetry with annotations can be accomplished with only a few lines of code: Add the@Logged annotation to your main robot class and to the classes it references, like subsystems...

link_counts.title: New for 2025: Robot Telemetry with Annotations (Java Only) — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
Ryan_Blue:

This is usually caused by out of date tags (which are used to determine the base version). Fetching tags from upstream should fix it

I had cloned from a private fork of the official repo, I think that the tags get lost on fork, so that explains that. I’m rebuilding…

Ryan_Blue:

You might have some luck adding the dependencies manually (in the dependencies block)- be sure to add the annotation processor too.

ugh. don’t know gradle well enough to do that. Suggestions for appropriate reference material or examples are welcomed.

posts.name: Sam Carlberg
posts.cooked:
Add these at the top of the dependencies block:

The setup you posted looks a little off to me, the wpilib and wpimath versions should be '2025.424242.+'

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
SamCarlberg:

The setup you posted looks a little off to me, the wpilib and wpimath versions should be '2025.424242.+'

I had cloned from a private fork of the official repo, I think that the tags get lost on fork, so that explains why I got a 2023 date in my local maven repo. I’m rebuilding from a clone of the official repo…

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked: Working! Actual credit for solution belongs to @Ryan_Blue and @SamCarlberg . My problem was a combination of not having the proper git tags in my local repository, and not yet having the Epilogue dependencies in build.gradle.
